page.title: 03THE MEDIEVAL SLABS OF HANLEY
page.content: In medieval Hanley there was an old open market near to St John's Church. There were long pathways joining Hanley to other villages.When it was raining the pathways got very muddy when the horses,peddlars and monks walked on them,so the people put stone slabs on the paths.Some are still there now.The market near to St John's Church had pack horses to carry the goods which had to be sold.The pathway joined Hanley market and led to Cobridge and Tunstall markets.The slab pathways were built on high ground to protect the people using them.They could walk and look out for robbers and murderers who might attack them. A lot of the old buildings have been knocked down now, but St John's Church is old.In fact it is the oldest building standing in Hanley today.
